705754f-a.text:

704598f-a.title: Brooklyn: Furman Street - Montague Street
704598f-a.text:
Furmen Street, at Montague Street, showing at the left, is a part of
the original Jawes S. Nockwell place, later owned by Litehfiel4. The house
at the right, in the hollow, used as a saloon is on the S.W. corner of Furnan
and Montague Streets.
1922.
Eugene L. Arwbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
704598f-a.folder: Furman Street & Montague Street, Brooklyn, NY

705758f-b.title: Brooklyn: Montague Street - Furman Street
705758f-b.text:
(1)
Montague Street, west to Furman Street, showing at the right, the
A.A. Low residence, No. 3 Pierrepont Place, and at the left, a section
of No. 2 Montague Terrace, the Litchfield home.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, showing a more inclusive view of the A.A. Low resi-
dence.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

705757f-a.title: Brooklyn: Montague Street - Furman Street
705757f-a.text:
(1)
Montague Street, north side, east from Furman Street. In the
center background, is the Residence of Henry E. Pierrepont.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, showing the viaduct over Montague Street, at the upper
right, and the construction of Montague Street itself.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

705755f-a.title: Brooklyn: Montague Street - Furman Street
705755f-a.text:
(1)
Montague Street, west to Furman Street, showing from left to right,
MMontague Terrace and Pierrepont Place, connected by the pedestrians foot-
bridge. At the left, is the Litchfield Mansion, at No. 1 Montague
Terrace, to the right is the mansion of A.A. Low at No. 3.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, showing a section of the Litchfield property, and to he
east, the East River and a faint outline of Manhattan.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

704597f-a.title: Brooklyn: Furman Street - Montague Street
704597f-a.text:
Furman Street, west side, north from above Montague Street. A rear
view of warehouses on the East River, facing Furman Street. I1 the back-
ground, is the Brooklyn Bridge. The Pierrepont Stores at rirht foreground,
were first occupied in 1868.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
